MDSC190
Notes
Module will sit in MSc Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery programme, added to Year 3 and 4 optional modules

Overview

Overview
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. One such course is currently delivered as an NHS delivered surgical education event within Liverpool and in addition this course integrates the unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Such cadavers receive full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility, typically the University of Liverpool Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one-week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting (cadaveric), supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region.
The assessment will comprise a summative oral presentation of a case report supported by robust evidence base; a summative written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills within the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Emphasis is made of the formative nature of the practical surgical skills component of the module. This is critically important to ensure that the module supports the development of essential surgical skills in all delegates rather than becoming a mechanism for credentialing in clinical practice which is the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes. The formative nature of assessment importantly facilitates multiple opportunities to provide feedback, to support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
Educational Aims
The module will:
1. Equip the higher surgical trainee (HST) with the underpinning theory of H&N reconstruction techniques based on robust evidence and practical demonstration.
2. Facilitate HST development of complex specific surgical skills in Head and Neck Surgery (complex perforator and composite free tissue transfer) in a safe and simulated environment with direct support and immediate guidance and critique.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. The Liverpool Advanced Head & Neck Reconstructive Anatomy Course is one such course with a full week of practical education with the additional unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Each cadaver receives full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting, supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region. The assessment will comprise an oral presentation of a case report, supported by robust evidence base; written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills in the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Outline Syllabus
1.Decision making processes in free tissue transfer techniques and options for Head & Neck Reconstruction.
2.Principles of soft tissue and composite surgical reconstruction with specific focus on mandibular, midfacial and skull base defects.
3.Surgical options and pathways for reconstruction, including perioperative investigations/protocols, planning technologies and techniques.
4.Practical virtual surgical planning for mandibular and midfacial defects with generation of surgical guides, fixation (plating) techniques and their perioperative fabrication. Understanding of planning procedures, limitations and complications.
5.Advanced surgical anatomy for perforator and complex composite free tissue transfer
6.Free tissue transfer insetting techniques and considerations, orientation of tissue components and planning for successful microvascular anastomosis.
7.Critical awareness of immediate, early and late surgical complications and their avoidance / effective management; Donor site morbidity, complications and rehabilitation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The taught/demonstrated content of this module has been developed by module leads with relevant expert knowledge and clinical experience.
The teaching and demonstration is undertaken by a faculty of clinical academics and surgical experts with robust knowledge and skills developed through their practice as H&N reconstructive surgeons.

The module utilises research-connected teaching from an expert faculty in keeping with the overarching ambitions of the Liverpool curriculum framework. This hallmark of University of Liverpool teaching supports the development of students clinical understanding and thinking through use of up to date and cutting edge research findings and clinical technologies.
Similarly learning will be though practical as well as theoretical understanding with students achieving technical surgical skills via cadaveric dissection under direct expert supervision. This active learning will cement understanding through practical, procedural approaches with achievement of increasing technical proficiency and understanding.

The teaching method and content is based on a strong prior knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge in keeping with senior higher surgical trainees (HST), underpinned by basic and clinical sciences with clinical practice and research. It is expected that, in addition to the taught component detailed below, delegates will undertake a period of additional self-directed learning and prior reading such that they are fully availed of the literature pertaining to free tissue harvest techniques and compositions. Such prior knowledge will be vital for both satisfactory completion of the technical elements of the module and also to support understanding and success in the oral presentation and written assignments.

The design of the intensive week long module gives students the opportunity to learn through observation (from faculty demonstration), consultant led simulated (cadaveric) assistance and through hands-on experience. This ensures the University hallmark of ‘active-learning’ and confidence building (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). These simulated surgical procedures will be captured by students through their e- portfolios (‘Digital fluency’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework), (Assessment 3:formative assessment). The assignments will be negotiated with module supervisors (course work, assessment 1&2) and are based on clinic activities with integration of evidence base and articulation of learning points and outcomes.

Delegates will be exposed to expert opinion from nationally and internationally recognised experts in the clinical elements of these complex surgical techniques, this will ensure an understanding of ‘global citizenship’ (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) through an appreciation of the application of these techniques/technologies in different cultural and geographical environments.
Case-based learning (CBL) (‘active learning’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) is used to help students apply knowledge they have learnt from their own reading, lectures, other didactic content and surgical/clinical prior experience. CBL is built on the basis of learning through discussion, giving students an opportunity to learn from scenario-based dialogue, and to understand that much of their practice is about managing uncertainty and risk, with decisions based upon knowledge of possibilities available at any given time. It facilitates evolution of the module over time as practice itself evolves also

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures will be given at the start of each surgical skills session, covering the salient methods to be developed in the practical session. The learning and teaching delivered in this module will be informed and refreshed by research and best evidence alongside expert clinical opinion from international calibre faculty with relevant surgical experience (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Teaching Method 2 – Tutorial with Case Based Learning
Description: illustrative cases used to develop understanding and critical decision making.
This will be both a) face to face for clinical cases requiring specific reconstructive decision making and b) virtual, for virtual surgical planning sessions for development of understanding of critical steps and decision making in custom planned composite reconstructions.
Teaching Method 3 - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Description: Trainees will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skills development in a simulated setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical practice case, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment and expert and student feedback/critical evaluation of each surgical case will be documented in a portfolio of clinical skills development. This will support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and be a resource to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
There will be a competence-based marking system which will be overt to the student in advance, and this will be aligned to the marking criteria for the national intercollegiate surgical skills examinations; thus, supporting the development of the trainee in a formative capacity in preparation for that examination.

Candidates will maintain their portfolio of clinical skills allowing it to be uploaded to clinical training portfolios of experience (as simulated surgical procedures). In the UK this is represented by the ISCP (intercollegiate surgical curriculum programme) whilst in other nations the respective system currently in use will apply for international candidates. Where no surgical training portfolio exists, the portfolio of work can be retained in paper/electronic format as a standalone record of clinical skills. Inclusion of the practical simulated skills development method with its formative assessment is vital to ensure that the module supports the development of technical abilities linked to anatomical knowledge. This approach ensures that this module is not utilised as a mean to provide credentialling of clinical capabilities, as should remain the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes within individual countries.

The faculty and module lead will review the content of learning annually to ensure the most current skills and techniques are being included for learning. In addition the approach to learning will be reviewed through appraisal of the module by delegates through feedback sessions.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
Assessment methods are designed in keeping with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and seek to assure that delegates will be have the opportunity to demonstrate both higher order thinking and critique needed for clinical practice, .
Focusing on the complexities of Head & Neck reconstruction for extended ablative defects. These assessments have been specifically developed for higher-level surgical trainees in oral & maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) with authentic assessments and deliberate focus on competencies needed for professional exams and for advanced surgical practice.
Requirement for all potential delegates to provide evidence of prior surgical capabilities sufficient to undertake advanced head and neck reconstruction in clinical practice (eg. Letter of support from Training programme director (TPD) or Institution lead/head of service recommendation of abilities) will assure individual candidates have capability to achieve necessary skill development (assessment 3)

Assessment 1 Oral (40%)
A 20 minute oral presentation†, aided by prepared slides, during which the student will outline the clinical presentation, diagnostics and surgical management of the case. Student will provide critical appraisal of the case management underpinned by the relevant evidence base; after which, there will an oral defence of this management plan for 5 minutes.
The inclusion of pass/fail element will ensure that a delegates reach a level and as such demonstrate suitable critique of available evidence alongside the higher order thinking needed to fabricate and defend a definitive management plan

Assessment 2 Course work (60%)
A 3000 word written assignment, which is a critical reflection of the management strategy, professional issues and patient outcomes, based upon, and/or stimulated by learning opportunities, from a complex H&N reconstruction case† into which the trainee has had significant input in their oral & maxillofacial surgical practice. Students will be offered the opportunity of a draft submission, for formative feedback. The written assignment should include a review of the literature pertaining to the case (or a significant/critical component of that case)
The written course work should reach a standard that demonstrates that the delegates have grasped the complexity of taught information and have suitably collated and presented the available evidence for their chosen topic alongside satisfactory critique of that evidence.

† At all times, students will ensure that their assessment materials/presentations/course work adheres to the strict principles of confidentiality and data protection such that any material/clinical detail is both sourced in accordance with appropriate consents and completely anonymised (full details and requirements included in student handbook).

Assessment 3: Formative - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Candidates will be required to complete 10 assessed reconstruction procedures during the formative assessment of skills and understanding. To achieve this, candidates will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skill development sessions in a simulated (cadaveric) setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical reconstructive technique, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment will include both expert and student (self) critique/critical evaluation of each surgical case documented within a portfolio of clinical skills.
It is not intended to mark / pass/ fail in this element as it is accepted that:
i.candidates will attend in different stages of their surgical training with different levels of practical skill,
ii.the formal assessment of surgical skills should be carried out during their ongoing clinical training environment and is not possible as a single snapshot in a simulated environment.
These experiences will be captured by workplace-based assessment (WBA), allowing routine recording of clinical and practical procedural skills undertaken by students in the simulated environment. The WBA format means students are given immediate feedback by a faculty (senior surgeons with clinical experience of cases) each time they are observed for a WBA; this ‘actionable’ feedback helps students identify what they are doing well, where they can improve for next time and develop further, through a self-regulated learning skill set.

The practical assessment is not competency based as this programme is intended to support and enhance professional training, not to take the place of credentialing as this is beyond scope and intention of the programme. The role of credentialing a surgeon ability sits with GMC or Royal Colleges. However, if our students need further assistance we will initiate the support process. Under such circumstances, we will encourage further practical skills development through a referral back the relevant TPD or Institution lead/head of service such that further development can be undertaken within the clinical setting under direct supervision (as would the case in any higher surgical training environment).

Guidance regarding the format of all assessments will be provided in the module handbook including data protection and confidentiality requirements as noted above.
Standard University assessment policies will apply, resit options as described in the Code of Practice on Assessment

In line with all other modules, a regular review of the assessment strategy for MDSC190 will be undertaken with the pathway lead and other module leads. This will seek to ensure that the assessments remain fit for purpose and evolve where necessary in response to potential changes in the module or in the delegates undertaking it.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically appraise the evidence base with respect to complex head and neck reconstruction within context of the treatment planning of an exemplar case of a head and neck surgical defect.
Liverpool campus · Semester 3 · Part-time
 LO2 Critically appraise evidence available for avoidance of complications when planning head and neck reconstructive surgery.
Liverpool campus · Semester 3 · Part-time
 LO3 Systematically apply theoretical understanding of advanced, complex, free tissue transfer (free flap) surgical skills in a safe, simulated environment, specifically in the harvest of soft tissue perforator flaps (under loupe control) and of complex composite free flaps including chimeric flaps.
Liverpool campus · Semester 3 · Part-time
 LO4 Systematically apply theoretical understanding of advanced, complex, custom planned free tissue transfer utilising virtual surgical planning technologies
Liverpool campus · Semester 3 · Part-time
 LO5 Critically analyse the design, development, and utilisation of custom cutting guides in both cancer resection, and related composite free flap harvest for reconstruction
Liverpool campus · Semester 3 · Part-time

These simulated surgical procedures will be captured by students through their e- portfolios (‘Digital fluency’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework), (Assessment 3:formative assessment). The assignments will be negotiated with module supervisors (course work, assessment 1&2) and are based on clinic activities with integration of evidence base and articulation of learning points and outcomes.

Delegates will be exposed to expert opinion from nationally and internationally recognised experts in the clinical elements of these complex surgical techniques, this will ensure an understanding of ‘global citizenship’ (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) through an appreciation of the application of these techniques/technologies in different cultural and geographical environments.
Case-based learning (CBL) (‘active learning’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) is used to help students apply knowledge they have learnt from their own reading, lectures, other didactic content and surgical/clinical prior experience. CBL is built on the basis of learning through discussion, giving students an opportunity to learn from scenario-based dialogue, and to understand that much of their practice is about managing uncertainty and risk, with decisions based upon knowledge of possibilities available at any given time. It facilitates evolution of the module over time as practice itself evolves also

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures will be given at the start of each surgical skills session, covering the salient methods to be developed in the practical session. The learning and teaching delivered in this module will be informed and refreshed by research and best evidence alongside expert clinical opinion from international calibre faculty with relevant surgical experience (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Teaching Method 2 – Tutorial with Case Based Learning
Description: illustrative cases used to develop understanding and critical decision making.
This will be both a) face to face for clinical cases requiring specific reconstructive decision making and b) virtual, for virtual surgical planning sessions for development of understanding of critical steps and decision making in custom planned composite reconstructions.
Teaching Method 3 - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Description: Trainees will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skills development in a simulated setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical practice case, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment and expert and student feedback/critical evaluation of each surgical case will be documented in a portfolio of clinical skills development. This will support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and be a resource to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
There will be a competence-based marking system which will be overt to the student in advance, and this will be aligned to the marking criteria for the national intercollegiate surgical skills examinations; thus, supporting the development of the trainee in a formative capacity in preparation for that examination.

Candidates will maintain their portfolio of clinical skills allowing it to be uploaded to clinical training portfolios of experience (as simulated surgical procedures). In the UK this is represented by the ISCP (intercollegiate surgical curriculum programme) whilst in other nations the respective system currently in use will apply for international candidates. Where no surgical training portfolio exists, the portfolio of work can be retained in paper/electronic format as a standalone record of clinical skills. Inclusion of the practical simulated skills development method with its formative assessment is vital to ensure that the module supports the development of technical abilities linked to anatomical knowledge. This approach ensures that this module is not utilised as a mean to provide credentialling of clinical capabilities, as should remain the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes within individual countries.

The faculty and module lead will review the content of learning annually to ensure the most current skills and techniques are being included for learning. In addition the approach to learning will be reviewed through appraisal of the module by delegates through feedback sessions.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
Assessment methods are designed in keeping with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and seek to assure that delegates will be have the opportunity to demonstrate both higher order thinking and critique needed for clinical practice, .
Focusing on the complexities of Head & Neck reconstruction for extended ablative defects. These assessments have been specifically developed for higher-level surgical trainees in oral & maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) with authentic assessments and deliberate focus on competencies needed for professional exams and for advanced surgical practice.
Requirement for all potential delegates to provide evidence of prior surgical capabilities sufficient to undertake advanced head and neck reconstruction in clinical practice (eg. Letter of support from Training programme director (TPD) or Institution lead/head of service recommendation of abilities) will assure individual candidates have capability to achieve necessary skill development (assessment 3)

Assessment 1 Oral (40%)
A 20 minute oral presentation†, aided by prepared slides, during which the student will outline the clinical presentation, diagnostics and surgical management of the case. Student will provide critical appraisal of the case management underpinned by the relevant evidence base; after which, there will an oral defence of this management plan for 5 minutes.
The inclusion of pass/fail element will ensure that a delegates reach a level and as such demonstrate suitable critique of available evidence alongside the higher order thinking needed to fabricate and defend a definitive management plan

Assessment 2 Course work (60%)
A 3000 word written assignment, which is a critical reflection of the management strategy, professional issues and patient outcomes, based upon, and/or stimulated by learning opportunities, from a complex H&N reconstruction case† into which the trainee has had significant input in their oral & maxillofacial surgical practice. Students will be offered the opportunity of a draft submission, for formative feedback. The written assignment should include a review of the literature pertaining to the case (or a significant/critical component of that case)
The written course work should reach a standard that demonstrates that the delegates have grasped the complexity of taught information and have suitably collated and presented the available evidence for their chosen topic alongside satisfactory critique of that evidence.

† At all times, students will ensure that their assessment materials/presentations/course work adheres to the strict principles of confidentiality and data protection such that any material/clinical detail is both sourced in accordance with appropriate consents and completely anonymised (full details and requirements included in student handbook).

Assessment 3: Formative - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Candidates will be required to complete 10 assessed reconstruction procedures during the formative assessment of skills and understanding. To achieve this, candidates will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skill development sessions in a simulated (cadaveric) setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical reconstructive technique, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment will include both expert and student (self) critique/critical evaluation of each surgical case documented within a portfolio of clinical skills.
It is not intended to mark / pass/ fail in this element as it is accepted that:
i.candidates will attend in different stages of their surgical training with different levels of practical skill,
ii.the formal assessment of surgical skills should be carried out during their ongoing clinical training environment and is not possible as a single snapshot in a simulated environment.
These experiences will be captured by workplace-based assessment (WBA), allowing routine recording of clinical and practical procedural skills undertaken by students in the simulated environment. The WBA format means students are given immediate feedback by a faculty (senior surgeons with clinical experience of cases) each time they are observed for a WBA; this ‘actionable’ feedback helps students identify what they are doing well, where they can improve for next time and develop further, through a self-regulated learning skill set.

The practical assessment is not competency based as this programme is intended to support and enhance professional training, not to take the place of credentialing as this is beyond scope and intention of the programme. The role of credentialing a surgeon ability sits with GMC or Royal Colleges. However, if our students need further assistance we will initiate the support process. Under such circumstances, we will encourage further practical skills development through a referral back the relevant TPD or Institution lead/head of service such that further development can be undertaken within the clinical setting under direct supervision (as would the case in any higher surgical training environment).

Guidance regarding the format of all assessments will be provided in the module handbook including data protection and confidentiality requirements as noted above.
Standard University assessment policies will apply, resit options as described in the Code of Practice on Assessment

In line with all other modules, a regular review of the assessment strategy for MDSC190 will be undertaken with the pathway lead and other module leads. This will seek to ensure that the assessments remain fit for purpose and evolve where necessary in response to potential changes in the module or in the delegates undertaking it.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
Module will sit in MSc Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery programme, added to Year 3 and 4 optional modules

Overview

Overview
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. One such course is currently delivered as an NHS delivered surgical education event within Liverpool and in addition this course integrates the unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Such cadavers receive full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility, typically the University of Liverpool Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one-week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting (cadaveric), supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region.
The assessment will comprise a summative oral presentation of a case report supported by robust evidence base; a summative written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills within the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Emphasis is made of the formative nature of the practical surgical skills component of the module. This is critically important to ensure that the module supports the development of essential surgical skills in all delegates rather than becoming a mechanism for credentialing in clinical practice which is the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes. The formative nature of assessment importantly facilitates multiple opportunities to provide feedback, to support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
Educational Aims
The module will:
1. Equip the higher surgical trainee (HST) with the underpinning theory of H&N reconstruction techniques based on robust evidence and practical demonstration.
2. Facilitate HST development of complex specific surgical skills in Head and Neck Surgery (complex perforator and composite free tissue transfer) in a safe and simulated environment with direct support and immediate guidance and critique.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. The Liverpool Advanced Head & Neck Reconstructive Anatomy Course is one such course with a full week of practical education with the additional unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Each cadaver receives full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting, supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region. The assessment will comprise an oral presentation of a case report, supported by robust evidence base; written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills in the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Outline Syllabus
1.Decision making processes in free tissue transfer techniques and options for Head & Neck Reconstruction.
2.Principles of soft tissue and composite surgical reconstruction with specific focus on mandibular, midfacial and skull base defects.
3.Surgical options and pathways for reconstruction, including perioperative investigations/protocols, planning technologies and techniques.
4.Practical virtual surgical planning for mandibular and midfacial defects with generation of surgical guides, fixation (plating) techniques and their perioperative fabrication. Understanding of planning procedures, limitations and complications.
5.Advanced surgical anatomy for perforator and complex composite free tissue transfer
6.Free tissue transfer insetting techniques and considerations, orientation of tissue components and planning for successful microvascular anastomosis.
7.Critical awareness of immediate, early and late surgical complications and their avoidance / effective management; Donor site morbidity, complications and rehabilitation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The taught/demonstrated content of this module has been developed by module leads with relevant expert knowledge and clinical experience.
The teaching and demonstration is undertaken by a faculty of clinical academics and surgical experts with robust knowledge and skills developed through their practice as H&N reconstructive surgeons.

The module utilises research-connected teaching from an expert faculty in keeping with the overarching ambitions of the Liverpool curriculum framework. This hallmark of University of Liverpool teaching supports the development of students clinical understanding and thinking through use of up to date and cutting edge research findings and clinical technologies.
Similarly learning will be though practical as well as theoretical understanding with students achieving technical surgical skills via cadaveric dissection under direct expert supervision. This active learning will cement understanding through practical, procedural approaches with achievement of increasing technical proficiency and understanding.

The teaching method and content is based on a strong prior knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge in keeping with senior higher surgical trainees (HST), underpinned by basic and clinical sciences with clinical practice and research. It is expected that, in addition to the taught component detailed below, delegates will undertake a period of additional self-directed learning and prior reading such that they are fully availed of the literature pertaining to free tissue harvest techniques and compositions. Such prior knowledge will be vital for both satisfactory completion of the technical elements of the module and also to support understanding and success in the oral presentation and written assignments.

The design of the intensive week long module gives students the opportunity to learn through observation (from faculty demonstration), consultant led simulated (cadaveric) assistance and through hands-on experience. This ensures the University hallmark of ‘active-learning’ and confidence building (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). These simulated surgical procedures will be captured by students through their e- portfolios (‘Digital fluency’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework), (Assessment 3:formative assessment). The assignments will be negotiated with module supervisors (course work, assessment 1&2) and are based on clinic activities with integration of evidence base and articulation of learning points and outcomes.

Delegates will be exposed to expert opinion from nationally and internationally recognised experts in the clinical elements of these complex surgical techniques, this will ensure an understanding of ‘global citizenship’ (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) through an appreciation of the application of these techniques/technologies in different cultural and geographical environments.
Case-based learning (CBL) (‘active learning’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) is used to help students apply knowledge they have learnt from their own reading, lectures, other didactic content and surgical/clinical prior experience. CBL is built on the basis of learning through discussion, giving students an opportunity to learn from scenario-based dialogue, and to understand that much of their practice is about managing uncertainty and risk, with decisions based upon knowledge of possibilities available at any given time. It facilitates evolution of the module over time as practice itself evolves also

Notes
Module will sit in MSc Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery programme, added to Year 3 and 4 optional modules

Overview

Overview
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. One such course is currently delivered as an NHS delivered surgical education event within Liverpool and in addition this course integrates the unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Such cadavers receive full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility, typically the University of Liverpool Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one-week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting (cadaveric), supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region.
The assessment will comprise a summative oral presentation of a case report supported by robust evidence base; a summative written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills within the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Emphasis is made of the formative nature of the practical surgical skills component of the module. This is critically important to ensure that the module supports the development of essential surgical skills in all delegates rather than becoming a mechanism for credentialing in clinical practice which is the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes. The formative nature of assessment importantly facilitates multiple opportunities to provide feedback, to support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
Educational Aims
The module will:
1. Equip the higher surgical trainee (HST) with the underpinning theory of H&N reconstruction techniques based on robust evidence and practical demonstration.
2. Facilitate HST development of complex specific surgical skills in Head and Neck Surgery (complex perforator and composite free tissue transfer) in a safe and simulated environment with direct support and immediate guidance and critique.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Head and Neck Reconstructive Surgery is a complex and highly technically challenging field central to the effective management of oncologic and other defects. Before operating on patients, trainees acquire key skills through operative exposure, assisting and directly supervised operating for basic reconstructive techniques however complex/advanced procedures require additional applied surgical anatomical and tissue handling skills that are not normally attainable without prior cadaveric dissection experience.

Internationally, there are very few practical and theoretical reconstruction courses designed solely for, led, and taught by expert head and neck surgeons. The Liverpool Advanced Head & Neck Reconstructive Anatomy Course is one such course with a full week of practical education with the additional unique element of taught virtual surgical planning technology learning; techniques which are otherwise only available within the clinical environment of specialist units (not currently taught elsewhere). Each delegate will be able to undertake virtual surgical plans for simulated free tissue transfer surgical procedures for head and neck reconstruction using the resource of cadavers. Each cadaver receives full-body fine-cut CT scanning to provide imaging data can then be manipulated virtually to generate patient-specific surgical cutting guides, templates, and reconstruction plates simulating completely all elements of the most complex of surgical procedure.
The course is suitable for higher level trainees in a surgical speciality related to Head and Neck Reconstruction, examples: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery, Plastic Surgery, Neurosurgery.

The course will take place in a suitable cadaveric dissection facility with access to both the wet lab environment for demonstrations, cadaveric prosections and delegate dissections. It will run over a one week intensive block and integrates over 30 hours of hands-on surgery in a simulated setting, supported by 15 hours of lectures and group tutorials. The block release is to facilitate attendance from trainees outside of the Mersey region. The assessment will comprise an oral presentation of a case report, supported by robust evidence base; written assignment and formative assessment of practical surgical skills in the simulated setting during the teaching week.
Outline Syllabus
1.Decision making processes in free tissue transfer techniques and options for Head & Neck Reconstruction.
2.Principles of soft tissue and composite surgical reconstruction with specific focus on mandibular, midfacial and skull base defects.
3.Surgical options and pathways for reconstruction, including perioperative investigations/protocols, planning technologies and techniques.
4.Practical virtual surgical planning for mandibular and midfacial defects with generation of surgical guides, fixation (plating) techniques and their perioperative fabrication. Understanding of planning procedures, limitations and complications.
5.Advanced surgical anatomy for perforator and complex composite free tissue transfer
6.Free tissue transfer insetting techniques and considerations, orientation of tissue components and planning for successful microvascular anastomosis.
7.Critical awareness of immediate, early and late surgical complications and their avoidance / effective management; Donor site morbidity, complications and rehabilitation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The taught/demonstrated content of this module has been developed by module leads with relevant expert knowledge and clinical experience.
The teaching and demonstration is undertaken by a faculty of clinical academics and surgical experts with robust knowledge and skills developed through their practice as H&N reconstructive surgeons.

The module utilises research-connected teaching from an expert faculty in keeping with the overarching ambitions of the Liverpool curriculum framework. This hallmark of University of Liverpool teaching supports the development of students clinical understanding and thinking through use of up to date and cutting edge research findings and clinical technologies.
Similarly learning will be though practical as well as theoretical understanding with students achieving technical surgical skills via cadaveric dissection under direct expert supervision. This active learning will cement understanding through practical, procedural approaches with achievement of increasing technical proficiency and understanding.

The teaching method and content is based on a strong prior knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge in keeping with senior higher surgical trainees (HST), underpinned by basic and clinical sciences with clinical practice and research. It is expected that, in addition to the taught component detailed below, delegates will undertake a period of additional self-directed learning and prior reading such that they are fully availed of the literature pertaining to free tissue harvest techniques and compositions. Such prior knowledge will be vital for both satisfactory completion of the technical elements of the module and also to support understanding and success in the oral presentation and written assignments.

The design of the intensive week long module gives students the opportunity to learn through observation (from faculty demonstration), consultant led simulated (cadaveric) assistance and through hands-on experience. This ensures the University hallmark of ‘active-learning’ and confidence building (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). These simulated surgical procedures will be captured by students through their e- portfolios (‘Digital fluency’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework), (Assessment 3:formative assessment). The assignments will be negotiated with module supervisors (course work, assessment 1&2) and are based on clinic activities with integration of evidence base and articulation of learning points and outcomes.

Delegates will be exposed to expert opinion from nationally and internationally recognised experts in the clinical elements of these complex surgical techniques, this will ensure an understanding of ‘global citizenship’ (Liverpool Curriculum Framework) through an appreciation of the application of these techniques/technologies in different cultural and geographical environments.
Case-based learning (CBL) (‘active learning’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) is used to help students apply knowledge they have learnt from their own reading, lectures, other didactic content and surgical/clinical prior experience. CBL is built on the basis of learning through discussion, giving students an opportunity to learn from scenario-based dialogue, and to understand that much of their practice is about managing uncertainty and risk, with decisions based upon knowledge of possibilities available at any given time. It facilitates evolution of the module over time as practice itself evolves also

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures will be given at the start of each surgical skills session, covering the salient methods to be developed in the practical session. The learning and teaching delivered in this module will be informed and refreshed by research and best evidence alongside expert clinical opinion from international calibre faculty with relevant surgical experience (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Teaching Method 2 – Tutorial with Case Based Learning
Description: illustrative cases used to develop understanding and critical decision making.
This will be both a) face to face for clinical cases requiring specific reconstructive decision making and b) virtual, for virtual surgical planning sessions for development of understanding of critical steps and decision making in custom planned composite reconstructions.
Teaching Method 3 - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Description: Trainees will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skills development in a simulated setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical practice case, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment and expert and student feedback/critical evaluation of each surgical case will be documented in a portfolio of clinical skills development. This will support critical reflection on the part of the delegate and be a resource to support future progression of skills following completion of the module.
There will be a competence-based marking system which will be overt to the student in advance, and this will be aligned to the marking criteria for the national intercollegiate surgical skills examinations; thus, supporting the development of the trainee in a formative capacity in preparation for that examination.

Candidates will maintain their portfolio of clinical skills allowing it to be uploaded to clinical training portfolios of experience (as simulated surgical procedures). In the UK this is represented by the ISCP (intercollegiate surgical curriculum programme) whilst in other nations the respective system currently in use will apply for international candidates. Where no surgical training portfolio exists, the portfolio of work can be retained in paper/electronic format as a standalone record of clinical skills. Inclusion of the practical simulated skills development method with its formative assessment is vital to ensure that the module supports the development of technical abilities linked to anatomical knowledge. This approach ensures that this module is not utilised as a mean to provide credentialling of clinical capabilities, as should remain the domain of higher surgical training pathways/schemes within individual countries.

The faculty and module lead will review the content of learning annually to ensure the most current skills and techniques are being included for learning. In addition the approach to learning will be reviewed through appraisal of the module by delegates through feedback sessions.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
Assessment methods are designed in keeping with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and seek to assure that delegates will be have the opportunity to demonstrate both higher order thinking and critique needed for clinical practice, .
Focusing on the complexities of Head & Neck reconstruction for extended ablative defects. These assessments have been specifically developed for higher-level surgical trainees in oral & maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) with authentic assessments and deliberate focus on competencies needed for professional exams and for advanced surgical practice.
Requirement for all potential delegates to provide evidence of prior surgical capabilities sufficient to undertake advanced head and neck reconstruction in clinical practice (eg. Letter of support from Training programme director (TPD) or Institution lead/head of service recommendation of abilities) will assure individual candidates have capability to achieve necessary skill development (assessment 3)

Assessment 1 Oral (40%)
A 20 minute oral presentation†, aided by prepared slides, during which the student will outline the clinical presentation, diagnostics and surgical management of the case. Student will provide critical appraisal of the case management underpinned by the relevant evidence base; after which, there will an oral defence of this management plan for 5 minutes.
The inclusion of pass/fail element will ensure that a delegates reach a level and as such demonstrate suitable critique of available evidence alongside the higher order thinking needed to fabricate and defend a definitive management plan

Assessment 2 Course work (60%)
A 3000 word written assignment, which is a critical reflection of the management strategy, professional issues and patient outcomes, based upon, and/or stimulated by learning opportunities, from a complex H&N reconstruction case† into which the trainee has had significant input in their oral & maxillofacial surgical practice. Students will be offered the opportunity of a draft submission, for formative feedback. The written assignment should include a review of the literature pertaining to the case (or a significant/critical component of that case)
The written course work should reach a standard that demonstrates that the delegates have grasped the complexity of taught information and have suitably collated and presented the available evidence for their chosen topic alongside satisfactory critique of that evidence.

† At all times, students will ensure that their assessment materials/presentations/course work adheres to the strict principles of confidentiality and data protection such that any material/clinical detail is both sourced in accordance with appropriate consents and completely anonymised (full details and requirements included in student handbook).

Assessment 3: Formative - Practical simulated surgical skills development
Candidates will be required to complete 10 assessed reconstruction procedures during the formative assessment of skills and understanding. To achieve this, candidates will have 10 x 3 hour surgical skill development sessions in a simulated (cadaveric) setting, with teaching and supervision by expert faculty on a 1:2 staff to student ratio. This will include formative clinical assessment of each simulated surgical reconstructive technique, conducted during the contact teaching week. The formative assessment will include both expert and student (self) critique/critical evaluation of each surgical case documented within a portfolio of clinical skills.
It is not intended to mark / pass/ fail in this element as it is accepted that:
i.candidates will attend in different stages of their surgical training with different levels of practical skill,
ii.the formal assessment of surgical skills should be carried out during their ongoing clinical training environment and is not possible as a single snapshot in a simulated environment.
These experiences will be captured by workplace-based assessment (WBA), allowing routine recording of clinical and practical procedural skills undertaken by students in the simulated environment. The WBA format means students are given immediate feedback by a faculty (senior surgeons with clinical experience of cases) each time they are observed for a WBA; this ‘actionable’ feedback helps students identify what they are doing well, where they can improve for next time and develop further, through a self-regulated learning skill set.

The practical assessment is not competency based as this programme is intended to support and enhance professional training, not to take the place of credentialing as this is beyond scope and intention of the programme. The role of credentialing a surgeon ability sits with GMC or Royal Colleges. However, if our students need further assistance we will initiate the support process. Under such circumstances, we will encourage further practical skills development through a referral back the relevant TPD or Institution lead/head of service such that further development can be undertaken within the clinical setting under direct supervision (as would the case in any higher surgical training environment).

Guidance regarding the format of all assessments will be provided in the module handbook including data protection and confidentiality requirements as noted above.
Standard University assessment policies will apply, resit options as described in the Code of Practice on Assessment

In line with all other modules, a regular review of the assessment strategy for MDSC190 will be undertaken with the pathway lead and other module leads. This will seek to ensure that the assessments remain fit for purpose and evolve where necessary in response to potential changes in the module or in the delegates undertaking it.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
